Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 05:15AM mradf wrote: Kendall, Just signed in and saw your post from a few minutes ago.  I am, thankfully, healing well from my surgery last week, and - with all this time on my hands - I'm coming on this website a lot and thinking a lot about you.  It's probably that whole Long Island, Breast Cancer Sisterhood thing.  And, I have younger sisters, too.  Maybe that's it.  This morning in Newsday, both surgeons that I had consulted with right after my diagnosis, including the one I used, were named in a special section as "HealthGrades Five-Star Doctors".  I was, once again, reassured that I was in good hands.  That feeling does not go away , so the selection process is important.  I kept a 99 cent spiral notebook and brought it with me to every appointment.  I listed questions I had for my doctors and noted what was discussed at every appointment.  I kept track of tests, as well.  And alway, always, always, who I spoke to at any doctor's office with date and time.  It was a very simple method but came in handy on many occasions when I could no longer remember who said what, and when.  It also helped my keep a mountain of insurance paperwork in check.  I paged through it this morning and remembered vividly the tests and the  decision making process.  I have to say without a doubt that having a consult with a PS and the genetic counseling/testing are key to making a well thought out decision.  $500 is a big nut to have to pay upfront to Dr. Maurer.  Hopefully you will get most of that back from your insurance co.  A note of caution on Sloan if you go that route - not every doctor and or medical center is necessarily "in network".  The hospital in NYC may be, but the surgeon or LI outpatient centers may not.  It's all very, very frustrating.  The new doctor, David I. Kaufman, seems to check out very well.  The website is impressive, but can be very subjective.  However, if you go to the NYS physician web profile, it all checks out.  No sanctions of any kind, and he's got a lot of experience.  Very reassuring.  He's also still listed as Chief of Surgery at New Island Hospital, which is most likely where the surgery would be.  Did he mention that?  Like everything else, a hospital stay is not as bad as you think.  If you need to stay, there is good reason, and it's very reassuring to be checked by the nurses 'round the clock.  And the hospital administerd pain medication isn't so bad, either.  All of this will begin to take the shape of a plan for you.  Your instincts will point you in the right direction.  If you have a primary care physician or gynecologist with whom you are comfortable, call them and ask for feedback.  You're doing fine. Be well, Maria

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 12:46AM mradf wrote: Good Morning Kendall, Based on my own research only, the one step procedure is probably one of the least often performed. You do have to meet certain guidelines, including size, and there is more use of an allograft material.  Google AlloDerm and you will get information on that in addition to what your PS tells you.  It is used in many implant reconstruction procedures, and was used in mine. I believe that not all PS's perform the one step, so you may need to expand your search.  Now, keeping in mind that many women come to this site because they need support early on, or for negative experiences, a women who posts here as "femme", and is from NY,  had a disasterous outcome with the one step.  If you search her, and send her a PM, I'm sure she can give you some direction. I have heard of other women on LI who have had it done successfully, however.  If you do a search on these boards as "immediate reconstruction with alloderm" you may find a few more women with experience.  A good source of reliable information about reconstruction overall is the website of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, which is www.plasticsurgery.org, both my PS and Dr. Cooper are members, which is important.  And the best source overall will be the PS.  If he does not give you this option, it's likely he does not do it.  If you ask him about it, he should tell you straight out whether he does these and how often and the outcomes.  Oh, another thing,  for any procedure you are considering, he should be able to refer you to a patient who is willing to share her experiences.  Write it all down in your notebook! Be well, Maria

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2009 11:01AM mradf wrote: Hey Kendall, Glad to see your update.  I can tell you are very relieved about the BRCA gene test.  I was negative, also.  Now go and get those B cups!  I was expecting a period near one of my scheduled surgeries, so I asked a nurse and she said it's not problem, just don't wear a tampon.  Sure enough I had it and I told the nurses in the hospital that morning.  I was able to keep my panties and a pad on into the OR, and a nurse very quickly and discreetly pulled them off and put a loose pad thingy under me.  Everyone is so focused on what they are doing in the OR that no one noticed what the nurse was doing.  I though I would get away with my cotton undies and a pad, but they said they had to come off in case they needed to use a catheter, which you may very well get during your surgery.  I had it for my mast w/recon.  Anyway, when I woke up in post op, there was a pad there, loose but doing it's job.  It's not like I had to get up and walk or anything!  It kinds of adds insult to injury to have to take this into consideration.  It's bad enough that every medical professional within driving distance has to look at our boobs, and everything near them, but they have to hear about our periods as well.  We might as well take out an ad in Newsday! So, you have barely three weeks to go.  Take some time to gather your comfy clothes (pull on pants and tops that zip up - your basic warm ups).  A recliner to sleep in at first.  Lots of pillows. If it has not already been discussed, ask your PS or a nurse about a post mastectomy camisole with pockets for the drains.  Get two, so you can rinse one out and always have a clean one. Insurance does cover them, and some BC coalitions donate them to the hospitals for the BC patients.  Do you have someone who will stay home with you at least the first few days?  You will really need someone to help you around at first, to put a meal together (even if it's take out or reheated), to reach for things, to help you bathe and shampoo, to bring you pain meds, to drive you to your first follow up appts.  There is a thread under "surgery - before, during and after" that offers a gazillion suggestions.  I will try to find it and "bump" it up for you.  We're with you all the way.  Be well, Maria

Have you made a decision yet about your own reconstruction?  Some procedures will come with  significant downtime which I imagine will be a challenge with the children. How old are they?  Do you have anyone nearby to help when you have surgery - parent, sibling?  That may help guide your decisions.  Keep in mind that you can have a mast then be reconstructed any time in the future.  Be well, Maria

On one hand, her quick passing following the recent news that she had maybe weeks to live does not surprise me.  My sister went to the grocery store with her daughter this past June 18th,  she began slipping away from us during the day on June 18th, and passed peacefully just after midnight on the morning of June 19th.  On the other hand, part of a story I read this morning does surprise me.  On AOL's home page is a link to a "Politics Daily" story by Melinda Henneberger which includes the following passage about a campaign event in April '07: "...As they both took questions afterward, Elizabeth was asked about the need for more public education about mammograms, and as she answered, the gym was stunned into complete silence: "It had a chance to migrate because I sat at home doing whatever I thought was important and didn't get mammograms. ... I do not have to be in this situation. I am responsible for putting myself, this man" -- here she gestured towards her husband -- "my family and, frankly, all of you at risk, too. Because I think you deserve to vote for this man." What she was saying -- and everybody there understood the implicit message -- was: I am going to die before my children get to high school because I didn't get a mammogram..." Who knew!?   The irony is that my sister was vigilant about screenings (as was I), and Mrs. Edwards was not.  By all accounts they both showed amazing strength and grace, and neither deserved this. Be well, Maria

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2009 09:47AM mradf wrote: Hey Kendall, I just found you and see that you are from LI, like me.  I'm from Suffolk County, South Shore.  I have a friend in Nassau County who has a family history and goes to Dr. Virginia Maurer for her breast exams.  She absoultely adores her.  Maybe if you ask, they will work with your out of network insurance coverage.  But, do not despair that there are no other "best" surgeons on LI, or certainly NYC if you are willing to travel.  I believe I found the "best" nearby, and he was trained in surgical oncology at Sloan.  He was not in my plan, but was willing to work with my out of network benefits, as was my plastic surgeon.  In both cases, their staff explained this when I called their offices.  Another "best" is Karen Kostroff on the North Shore who was my neighbor's surgeon.  She too does not participate in any plans, and her receptionist offered no help or advice whatsoever when I called for a consult.  My neighbor offered me several other names for consults when I was first diagnosed, too, and I still have them.  If you want the name of my surgeons, I will PM you.  From Westbury it may be just as close (but not necessarily as easy) to go to NYC.  One thing I always do is check out any doctor I use on the NYS Physician Web Profile, to be sure they have no disciplinary actions or hospital privileges revoked.  I can send you that link as well.  I believe there are quite a few of us from LI on this website, and we can say that LI is like a double edged sword.  A high rate of breast cancer, but some of the best medical care available.  I'm three days out from surgery for reconstruction, yet I feel so lucky to have to to doctors I have. I noticed in one of your posts you were ordered to stop research for 24 hours.  I can relate to that!  All my doctors discovered I was an information junkie and I had to temper that with the idea that, in some cases, a little knowledge is a bad thing, and could not compare with their wealth of education and experience.  I would finish every appointment with the question "what did I not ask that I should have?"  and in most cases, I hit all my marks, but in some cases they came forth with great information and advice.  Bottom line is I had surgeons who were highly recommended and very experienced, and with whom I felt very comfortable.  In answer to some of your other questions, I had full MRI, pelvis included, CT scans, and all the biopsies offered.  As far as oncology, I did not have a consult until after surgery and had my pathology report.  I did not need chemo or radiation because the surgeon "got it all" and it was not invasive.    That was my goal, and the price of admission for that was my breasts.  But I just got them back! You sound very bright and you live in a great area and you are asking all the right questions so you will do fine. Be calm, be well. Maria

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 07:21AM mradf wrote: So here's your PS:  http://www.robertcoopermdplasticsurgery.com/ and his NYS credentials check out, as well.  If you are having any reconstruction done, you will see him a lot and will need to feel comfortable with him - and he should make you feel that way at your first consult.  You may be close to having your team!  And the hospital's affiliation as part of the NS/LIJ network is a good thing.  When I needed to cancel the first doctor, I had actually scheduled a surgery with her- so I just said that I felt I was moving too fast (true) and needed time to think about my options (true) and wanted to postpone.  Every doctor and nurse told me, however, that it's very common, and the surgeons do not take it personally.  You are going to speak to their assistant of some sort anyway, and if the doctor is curious enough, he or she will call, most likely out of concern.  I would use a simple, succinct line like: "I have found a surgeon to whom I was referred, and with whom I am very comfortable, and who also happens to be in my network, and I have decided to use him.  Please thank doctor so and so for all he/she has done to help me during this stressful time."  It will be fine.  If they ask you who you are using, tell them.  My first surgical consult's assistant did follow up and call to ask what I had decided and she was very understanding.  My surgery last week was a good thing.  It was the "exchange" step of the reconstruction, and it went well.  I was "curvy" so giving up my breasts was something that affected my outward appearance, which ran a distant second to survival, but I am glad I opted for the reconstruction. I opted for bi-lateral mastectomies (one side had cancer and one side was prophylactic) and this type of reconstruction.  Depending on what surgery you elect to have, you will come to learn all the lingo, but, if you opt for mastectomy with immediate reconstruction, a common method is to place tissue expanders were breast tissue used to be.  Basically, they are temporary implants which eventually get exchanged out for permanent implants.  I'll leave all the details to your PS consult. I had a few complications post mastectomy, so there have been some delays, but I have no regrets and would choose the same path again if I had to.  Fortunately, I have a very supportive husband and family as well as a very supportive work environment.  About 15 years ago I left the corporate world (I was a bank manager) to raise my children, then returned to a much more casual work environment (I am an office manager for a small commercial carpentry company).  I went from suits and heels to jeans and flats. I even have my own hardhat with a little pink BC ribbon on it in case I have to go to a jobsite.  Three months after re-entering the workforce, I had a routine mammogram and BAM!  Life was turned upside down.  I may have gotten more financial support from a corporate environment in terms of better disability income, but I never would have had the same emotional support I have gotten from the blue collar environment.  We have medical insurance and I collect the max NY disability, so we survive, and I am aware that we are more fortunate than many . So, I am going to brave the "meet the teacher night" at my daughter's high school.  I feel well enough and found a suitable outfit that doesn't look like PJ's or hurt any of the incisions.  Keep us posted. Be well, Maria

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 02:26PM - edited Mar 7, 2008 02:29PM by mradf RELIEF AT LAST! Today, at 3 weeks and 1 day post surgery, the drains were removed. I can't wait to try to get to sleep in my own bed tonight!  If too soon, the trusty recliner is always there. Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2009 02:03AM mradf wrote: 2new1s, I just searched for BC/BS position statement on Alloderm (in a few different ways) and got returns from BCBS Florida and Kansas.  Florida's statement says it is "considered experimental", but Kansas' statement said it is "considered medically necessary when used in a breast reconstruction following mastectomy".  I can't get a position statment from BCBS of Illinois.  It's owned by Health Care Services Corp. and I can't get a position statement from that, either.  Or the BCBS Association.  It doesn't mean they don't have a position statement, I just can't find it online.  Most people will tell you to have your surgery, then worry about what is and is not covered.  You cannot control everything.  You may be in a network hospital with a non-network anesthesiologist, etc.    Since you're already not sleeping and all worked up over this, be pro-active and contact your insurer tomorrow. Tell them that you want to know their position on the use of allograft products in connection with breast reconstruction following medically necessary mastectomy.  DO NOT let them tell you that your surgery is not medically necessary!  You are BRCA + with a family  history, if I remember, and this surgery is one of your options.  If you get the runaround, tell them that you are going to contact your congressional representative and/or your state department of health to get help and guidance.  Now, as to your PS's staff telling you they have to submit a claim to Lifecell - what for!?  Is Lifecell going to cover the cost or donate the stuff? The other option is to do nothing, concentrate on getting from pre surgery to post surgery and then deal with it all.  All I did was make sure that the surgeons got pre certifications from my insurance company for my surgeries and hospital stay.  Oh, my PS used alloderm on me.  I really can't tell if it made a difference - because what can I compare it to? - but I trust he knew what he was doing.  This is the issue I want to take on when I'm "finished" because I was put through the insurance trials.  If found that if I did my research and said the right things, I got satisfaction.  Knowledge is power.  Let us know how it goes. Be well, Maria

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 06:25PM mradf wrote: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/91/topic/699896 Ruby, This thread, and some others like it, have a wealth of first hand information and recommendations.  There are some others.  If I can find them I will bump them up or copy the link for you. They were a great help to me last year.  Going up and down the stairs was not a problem for me at all, but I could not sleep in my bed for some time.  I camped out on the main floor in a recliner with tons of pillows.  I let my legs help push me up as my arms were weak and tender for a few days.  In your case, you will have the abdomen weak as well.  It's a sure bet that "Mom" will be quite busy for the first few days, at least.  She will most likely need to help you up, help you wash, empty your drains, prepare meals, do laundry,  and drive you to your follow up appointments.  Soon enough, your strength will come back and you will be able to do a little more for yourself each day.  Looks like your diagnosis is similar to mine.  Good luck and be well. Maria

Posts.Content: May 3, 2008 02:53PM mradf wrote: Wow Ladies, I mean WOW! Some of you are really putting down those feelings most of us have about coming to this site for support and understanding.  Annie, I'm so glad you didn't leave. Funny thing is, about a week ago, I wasn't checking in so often.  I felt better, and like I didn't need the "fix".  I was cleared for work this coming Monday, 5/5, and had a lot to do to get back into the swing.  So I did.  I apparently did too much.  But, who knew?  I had no restrictions.  No one said specifically "do not pick up, load, and unload two cases of water on sale this week only for $3.88 limit 2".  Anyway, late Sunday night, during a typical Sunday night insomnia session (God does work in strange ways), while I was wide awake, a blood vessel ruptured above one of my "under reconstruction" boobs, swelled to the size of a football within one minute and, after calling the PS and 911, I had emergency surgery, #3,  and lost a lot of blood.  I almost needed a transfusion, but a shot of "procrit" and iron supplements seems to be working.  I was admitted for two days and am home now with a lot of restrictions. This may seem off topic, but I'm getting to my point. I have kind of felt since my pathology that I am not really a "victim" of BC since I do not need chemo or radiation. I almost feel, and I haven't voiced this to anyone else yet, like a fraud. My BC support nurse has already told me it's okay to feel what I really feel.  That having the initial diagnosis and bi-lat masts w/recon is enough to justify occasional feelings of frustration and despair, and that was  before surgery #2 to replace an expander following a staph infection. Back in the hospital this week, with the pink BC bracelet on to identify my status, and being visited by the special BC nurses, made me realize I am a "victim" of BC!  No matter how strong I am when I look at myself in the mirror and see what I see, I am still one of you.  I deserve and need to be here.  Despite the love and support I get at home, from my friends and my medical team, no one does it better than you ladies here.  I do feel like shedding a tear, but the anti-depressent is working well.  Or maybe it's just PMS.  I wonder how that will affect my blood. Thank you all. Be well, Maria

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 03:37PM - edited Apr 16, 2008 03:39PM by mradf Jody, It sounds like the doctor is suggesting mastectomy for both medical and cosmetic reasons.  I had bi-lateral mastectomies with reconstruction on Feb. 14th, and a second surgery 1 week ago to replace an expander after infection.  I know that when I was deciding on surgery, the doctors made it clear that, in my case,  I could do either lumpectomy with radiation, or mastectomy, but for some women the choice is quite clear and the breast surgeon said he would recommend that to the patient.  I would put a lot of  weight on the doctors opinion.  You're already 2 surgeries in without really clear margins.  You are very young, with a long life ahead of you.  I am 47 and I feel the same way.  I am now cancer free, and treatment free, and my new boobs are in the works.  I have no regrets. Look for BethNY on these boards, who underwent bi-lateral mastectomies with reconstruction in her 20's, and not all that long ago, so she's very up to date with information. Be well and good luck.  Maria

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 08:28PM mradf wrote: I think you may get more information from the website http://www.hystersisters.com/.  One of my sisters has had many gynecological oncology surgeries, and I sent her that link.  I was recently on that site looking for info on prophylactic oopherectomy.  It's similar to this, but all about the lower half. As far as doing everything together, I'm thinking that if it's okay with the doctors, why not?  I would have asked, too. As far as the MRSA goes, that's a risk anytime.  Use all the pre-surgical precautions I've read about, like using a special soap before surgery and so on.  Keep us posted, because you will not be the first one to have to do this. Good luck and be well, Maria
